newsitem.title: SIERRA LEONE: Lightning kills at least 25 in Sierra Leone boat.
newsitem.headline: Lightning kills at least 25 in Sierra Leone boat.

text.p: Lightning struck a boat carrying West African traders off Sierra Leone, killing at least 25 out of more than 70 passengers, police said on Wednesday.
About 40 passengers were still missing, feared dead.
Police said 25 bodies had been dragged from the wreck of the boat, which split in two when it was hit by a bolt of lightning 10 miles off the Sierra Leone town of Kambia on Tuesday night.
"Survivors said there were more than 70 passengers on board the boat but only 35 -- the 25 dead and 10 rescued -- have been brought ashore," said a police officer in Kambia.
Staff at the Baptist Hospital in nearby Kasire said 20 bodies had been taken to the mortuary there.
"Some of the bodies have had to be buried as they were already decomposing. Relatives of the passengers have been storming the hospital for information," one said.
Search parties of police and local fishermen continued to look for survivors or bodies 15 hours after the accident.
The boat was travelling from the Guinean capital Conakry to Freetown and passengers were mostly Guinean or Sierra Leonean.
Boat accidents are common in Sierra Leone, where dilapidated roads are made doubly unsafe by armed guerrillas, and traders resort increasingly to the use of river transport.
Thirty people drowned in an accident last month and nearly 300 have perished in boat disasters in the last four months.
